content: I just 3d printed and painted a bunch of these pretty sweet little dwarf
miniatures and in this week's video I'm gonna be hand crafting them some
hopefully pretty cool modular dwarf themed terrain
hey guys welcome back to black magic
crafts this week's episode is sponsored by titan forge and they are the
inspiration for this week's build titan forge is a company that models and sells
really high quality themed miniatures that you can download and print yourself
at home it's getting harder and harder to ignore the accessibility and cost
effectiveness of home 3d printing miniatures they make their
products available via patreon you pay 10 bucks a month get you in the door and
you get access to that month's set of models every month they release at least
12 miniatures 40-some bases and terrain it's a lot they release a lot every
single month that you get for 10 bucks it's pretty good the models are always
themed each month so February is dwarves and I decided to only print a couple of
the small ones because that's all I could get painted in time for this video
but this set includes some big-ass models that are really damn cool like a
big dragon and a crazy mech dwarf and a whole bunch of a really cool dwarven
themed terrain but every month is a different theme and next month they're
actually doing a split theme that's both sci-fi and fantasy but let's say you
don't want to join up to a subscription patreon thing for your files you don't
have to they actually make all of their previous models available for a la carte
purchasing via my mini factory comm you can go in there and just buy what you
want stuff from older sets whatever and the nice thing is that if you're a
current patron and you want to get some of the older models they do give a 50%
discount to current patrons for those older models so it's still a good deal
pretty good deal overall but I know something like ah 3d printing while the
sponsor for the video is 3d printing related the build is gonna be
handcrafted I was thinking of doing a diorama for these guys but the minis are
so cool I want to be able to use them in my game so I didn't want to tie them
into a diorama instead I'm gonna build some kind of modular terrain I don't
have any dwarven terrain in general one of the most used bits of
scatter train in my arsenal is my little pillars I figured it would make sense to
make some dwarven ones as they could instantly be dropped on any battle mat
or tiles and a moat that dwarven vibe my buddy Michael at TW s a few years ago
did a really nice set of dwarven form form form dwarven foam pillars I'm gonna
use that as inspiration for this build I haven't gone back to reference it I saw
that video a few years ago so I'm just gonna kind of do it from memory because
I want to kind of have come up with my own style for these but there's
certainly some inspiration there I will put a link to that video so you can
check that one out as well and maybe combine the two and figure out what's
best for you I don't have much of a plan wish me luck
I'm gonna be using XPS insulation foam and I am gonna be using the German
styrodur brand but I want to make it exceptionally clear here the only reason
I'm choosing this over the pink formula or the blue Dow it's the thickest one I
have on hand it doesn't matter what XPS foam you are using you want something
that is thick so you can make thick pillars and I only have half inch pink
foam ignore the fact I'm using this what matters is that it is there I'm gonna
cut some square pillars and then some octagon basis and for size it's gonna be
super scientific I'm not gonna measure this but based on this it's about 35
millimeters square that looks like a good size break a wire started filming
almost every single time never fails round to fight
all right for height I'm gonna be adding
bases to these which are gonna build them up in height so I don't need to be
too tall i ball we're gonna say 70 millimeters all the people who get mad
at imperial get the benefit today of me using the numbers on the table well
there we go let's just do this for the last one but I need a base and I think I
want these bases to be octagons first thing I'm going to do is break down some
of this giant piece here so I have an easier piece to work with don't worry
there's an open window now to make the octagon I'm gonna use this nifty little
jig from shifting lands slap your foam onto the jig and I'm just gonna guess
here on size and see how this what looks the way this works then is you take this
out of the jig and turn it and run it through again and you just repeat this
for all of the sides
now I have an octagon and it's a little large but that's okay because I think I
want to do two layers here I want to step it up and I can take this one shape
and break it down into however many pieces I need let's call it ten
millimeter but I'm not going to want it just to be like that I want another
layer so I'm gonna make another octagon that is smaller should have paid
attention to what I had to set at the first time but I'm winging it
all right all right all right that looks
pretty good now this is all well and good but what
makes dwarven architecture really cool and
interesting are those nice triangular pieces that are layered I need to make
some of those I'm going to take my extras here slice them down few
millimeters smaller than they already all are on all directions now I need to
cut these into a point I need to set my wire at the angle in theory I should
just be able to do that lift this and do that hopefully that's even yes those are
the same set this back to 90 degrees now I can cut these into very thin layers
so now I meet up some more blocks that
are the same as the first although I cut them a little bit shorter because the
idea is decoratively stacking these down lower but I also want them to be a
little bit narrower in this direction so the first thing I'm gonna do is just
shave off a little here on each side so that you get a stacking effect like this
again I'll just cut them down into thin slivers like the first ones
all right let's do some assembly line
work here we'll start with these bases I think I'm gonna use hot glue for these
two pieces so that they're bonded together real quick and easy the hot
glue gives me enough time to position them it sets up fast enough though as
soon as I let go we're done you know in retrospect maybe I should have actually
used PVA glue for this because the hot glue has a thickness and I've got a gap
here which I may or may not fill in later I'm not sure yet for these pieces
I am absolutely gonna switch to PVA glue a little bit of water for the brush and
we're just gonna start gluing I think my plan of attack here is gonna be put on
one side and then move on to the next pillar so that this can dry and not
slide around on me while I'm working we're gonna jump back and forth between
pillars here and make it real clear that I've never made these before I didn't
make a test piece this is me learning right along with you guys which is often
the case when I make my videos
so I learned a couple things doing this
one is that it actually didn't make sense to do one side then go to this one
then this one then this one and then back and turn it I wasn't very efficient
and also this glue takes too long to dry and even by the time I made it through
it wasn't dry yet so this point listen I just ended up doing one way all the way
around I also noticed that I had to use a fair bit of glue it's dangerous to put
it on too thin because then it dries out very quickly and doesn't make a good
bond so I was putting it on pretty heavy on the piece and I was also taking a
little bit of extra glue and wiping it on the bigger interior piece so that I
was gluing wet to wet which actually made the bond much stronger since I knew
I'd have to wait for this glue to dry I used at the same time to apply some
joint compound into the seams here to fill that gap that I'd mentioned earlier
this way I could take advantage of both of these things drying at the same time
I got to assemble these but before I do that I do want to add a little bit of
stone texture so I'm gonna do this separately while they're apart I don't
want to go too crazy with this I feel like dwarven stone texture architecture
is actually a lot smoother and nicer than maybe a decrepid dungeon or
something like that made by man or some other race if you want to add a little
bit of damage you can take like a knife and chop away some little tiny gouges
but again I wouldn't go too crazy with this you can add a little bit these if
you make this too extreme then it kind of negates all the nice carving work
that you did making all of these nice hard edges the top is a tricky thing now
in my mind I picture these representing pillars that actually go much taller to
a high ceiling so that's why I don't want to break these and make them
look textured or at a cap you could add a cap on it but then that represents
them being the top or you could chip away and make it look like the interior
of the stone but then it looks like ruined pillars I really want to imply
that these continue up to a really tall grand ceiling which makes finishing this
really tricky but I'm just gonna add a slight bit of texture just to kind of
blend it in with the rest and call it a day now to attach these could use hot
glue but I don't want to end up with that thickness problem again I think I
want to use PVA now this is gonna have one problem it's gonna take a long time
to dry it's gonna be hard to hold it in place so I want to try something here I
don't know if this is gonna work I'm gonna use a long screw and actually
attach the base to the pillar now hopefully this will pull them nice and
tight together and have the added bonus of adding a little bit of weight to the
piece these pillars have a very wide footprint so weight is not super
important these are not gonna fall over or move around on the table but adding a
little bit extra weight never hurts the nice thing with XPS foam is that a
screw actually will drive itself into it as long as you don't overdo it it will
actually hold and it sucks itself in countersinks itself and holds this very
very tightly so now I don't actually have to wait for this glue to set up to
move on to the next phase actually that pulled is so tight that it pulled out
some of this joint compound that wasn't quite cured yet which is nice so just
gotta do all of these and then actually let the joint compound dry up before
moving on to mod podge
we're moving along pretty darn good here I'm actually quite impressed with how
quickly I was able to get to this stage this is still day one and not quite a
full day of working and I got the pieces sculpted finished and Mod Podge so I can
start painting if you're new around here and you haven't heard me say this a
million times already the reason I put the Mod Podge on is to make the foam a
little bit more hard a little bit more durable and also seal up all those
points where you got the layers so nothing's peeling off and overall it
just makes everything more better so for the paint job I'm gonna keep it pretty
simple I'm just gonna use three tones of gray a dark gray a medium gray and a
light gray probably just homemade black wash may be all brush on some metallics
I'm not sure I'm thinking about maybe brushing on some Silver's or golds to
kind of tie in with these little dwarven dudes here I know it seems to make sense
we'll see I'm not sure let's paint these things
[Applause]
[Applause]
all right day one on this project is completed now the next day all of this
is nice and dry one small thing I would change if I were doing this again I
textured the stonework kind of after assembly or after these two separate
parts were assembled and that was a little bit of a mistake
because I wasn't able to get the texture on the top surface of the lower base and
it kind of shows after paint so in the future I would texture these pieces
before gluing them together not a big deal though I ended up not putting any
wash on these I just did dry brushing the three grays and then I dry brushed
with a metallic gold which I thought was a nice little touch to highlight the
edges and make it look more dwarven even though I mean like really why is that
more dwarven I don't know but it is it looks good this is technically done I
mean these are dwarven pillars they're good to go
they're done but I want to do something a little bit extra on some of them these
dwarves from Titan Forge they're not like typical dwarves they're a little
bit steampunky I guess they're definitely like inventors or tinkerers
they got all this crazy equipment they kind of remind me of the is it guild
from Ravnica if you're into MTG I want to make a couple of these pillars sort
of play on that theme and I want to make them look like they're in some kind of
dwarven steampunk ash and use the word steampunk cause I don't want to offend
anybody to love steampunk but I want to make them look kind of science lab II
add some pipes and machinery and stuff as if they're part of this dwarven
experimenters laboratory I'm not gonna do it to all of them because I want to
have some just plain for regular game use I'm thinking maybe I'll pick two of
them as kind of centerpiece ones to really embellish I went to Michael's and
I bought a whole bag of and stuff little beads and gems and
gears and pieces that I can use to adorn these with these sort of little bits
they're actually very very cheap when you consider them per piece the problem
is you gotta like buy these big packs and it actually can be a little bit
expensive to buy a bunch of packs when they're all like you know five to ten
dollars each and you're only gonna be using a few of them so I'm always really
reluctant to buy them and my collection of these kind of bits is actually a lot
smaller than some others I decided to you know buy a couple different things
that would be useful for this project and useful in the future I think for
other things let's play around and see what looks cool so I have an assortment
of these little round I don't know bubble bead jewel things I
thought they might look cool as kind of domes probably end up painting them
copper to match the metallic piping and whatnot but I picked this color because
I kind of has a cool oily iridescent look I also got a mix of gemstones that
are different colors that might look cool I already had some that are much
smaller but now I have a good range of big and small some gears that'll maybe
use but I'm gonna be careful I don't like the idea of just slapping gears on
things that don't make sense but I might use them as backing for these gems I
also already have some little ones here I might use I got a couple of different
wires and necklace things that look like cabling or rope and then I want to add
some pipes to this some copper pipes and originally I was planning on doing the
q-tip method the styrene rod or plastic rod method and bending it well what if I
just use some copper wire so I got some small gauge copper wire that I can
hopefully make into pipes the tricky part is making them straight enough to
look good because why are bends easily and I thought well why don't I just take
some regular household 14-2 wire strip it and that could also work it's a
little bit thicker gives me two different sizes and shows you an example
of something you might have kicking around I'm just gonna play around and
fiddle a bit and see where I get and at the end we can review what I ended up
working
[Applause]
[Applause]
[Applause]
[Applause]
[Applause]
[Applause]
well that actually turned out pretty darn cool it was a bit of a challenge
with the old shaky hands but all these little bits really did a nice job of
decorating these pillars in a really ridiculous way that kind of looks like
an insane dwarven laboratory I learned a few things along the way though while
the copper wire is nice to use because you can easily bend those corners and
unlike styrene rods or the plastic sticks or whatever you don't have to
heat them up but they're hard to keep straight because they're so soft they
want to wave a bit and I tried to straighten them out a bit with needle
nose didn't work great but I'm not gonna lose too much sleep over just something
to keep in mind if you're going that route also I found that when clipping
the wire with side cutters or the snipper on the needlenose it kind of
cuts to a point because it cuts and crimps which made it kind of difficult
to attach it to flat surfaces and this was the same with this necklace chain
that I use so it would be a good idea to keep a nail file not a nail file like a
metal file on hand to make a nice flat surface so that when you have your wire
it can butt in nicely I did find later Hobby snippers these kind of side
cutters did also cut a flatter cut than something like this I used this necklace
to make some cabling because it has a really great texture to it that kind of
looks like cabling but it was a challenge to work with it's floppy and
it doesn't just like hold its shape how you bend it and it's hard to bend it in
a tighter radius than this so it was a little bit tricky in the end you don't
work pretty darn cool I used a lot of actual copper here and you know this
kind of goldish copper chain in the hopes that I wouldn't have to paint
things but it's not really gonna work out that way it's not really cohesive
and sometimes real material doesn't look right in you know context with other
things that are painted so I'm gonna quickly take some of this copper paint
and just lightly paint out all of the real metal stuff the nice thing is
because it's already basically that color I don't have to be too finicky
also this will cover up the joints where I used a lot of super glue and
accelerant to make these joints and hold things in place there's a few spots
where that went a little bit crazy and caused some hazing
or maybe my little holes are too big I'm gonna actually go in with a little bit
of weathering probably and do some drips off of these pipes to hide that sort of
thing and then I think I can call these done
well I will say that personally I'm very
happy with this project what did you guys think did you enjoy it I hope that
you did if you did hit the like button let me know in the comment section below
it's kind of like a two phase or two tiered project one is just your basic
classic dwarven pillars that are super useful for D&D and I would assume some
war games and then you could take that idea and enhance it with some ridiculous
add-on bits to make it more steampunky and weird or if you don't want to do
dwarven stuff you could just take some of the ideas shown here and apply it to
other projects I want to thank Titan Forge for sponsoring this video and
mostly for inspiring this build with their cool models again if you want to
check them out I will put links in the description below now if you want to
build these but you're finding yourself discouraged because say you don't have a
hot wire cutter or whatever don't let that stop you don't let that limit you
this is stone work you can absolutely just make these by cutting things with a
blade it'll just require more time and
patience and you might not get the same degree of accuracy over many pieces but
doesn't really matter on stone work the hot wire table is really just a tool
that makes it easier you don't need it to make it please just understand you
don't need it to make it and even if you can't get foam take the idea find them
some material that you can't have heck make it out of cardboard and paper if
you want these just build them don't don't worry about what you do or do not
have over saying that if you do want to make your life easier and you want to
pick up some of the tools that I use to make my life easier head over to black
magic crafts dot CA there have links and listings of all the stuff that I use
regularly see why I use it and grab some for yourself if you like the videos that
I make here and you want to help me keep making them you can do so by supporting
the channel on patreon that support goes a long way to allowing me to dedicate
the time that it takes to make these videos each and every week also it gives
you access to a great little community of like
minded awesome crafters and cool people in the black magic crafts fellowship
that's it for this week guys I sincerely hope you learn something and got
inspired to build something cool for yourself I will see you again next week
Cheers
